trans-unit.source: Creating a New Device Function Driver
trans-unit.target: Creating a New Device Function Driver

trans-unit.source: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new device function driver.
trans-unit.target: In this topic we explain how to use Visual Studio to start writing a new device function driver.

trans-unit.source: Device function drivers are different from filter drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.
trans-unit.target: Device function drivers are different from filter drivers, software drivers, and file system drivers, which we cover in other topics.

trans-unit.source: To learn about device function drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see [What is a Driver?](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554678), [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652), and [Device Nodes and Device Stacks](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554721).
trans-unit.target: To learn about device function drivers and how they differ from other types of drivers, see [What is a Driver?](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554678), [Choosing a Driver Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554652), and [Device Nodes and Device Stacks](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff554721).

trans-unit.source: To begin, first determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in [Device and Driver Technologies](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff557557).
trans-unit.target: To begin, first determine where your device fits in the list of technologies described in [Device and Driver Technologies](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Ff557557).

trans-unit.source: To learn about which driver models are available for your device, see the documentation for that particular technology.
trans-unit.target: To learn about which driver models are available for your device, see the documentation for that particular technology.

trans-unit.source: The recommended driver model varies from one technology to the next.
trans-unit.target: The recommended driver model varies from one technology to the next.

trans-unit.source: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF) or the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF).
trans-unit.target: For some technologies, the documentation recommends using the User Mode Driver Framework (UMDF) or the Kernel Mode Driver Framework (KMDF).

trans-unit.source: For other technologies, the documentation explains how to create a minidriver that is part of a driver pair.
trans-unit.target: For other technologies, the documentation explains how to create a minidriver that is part of a driver pair.

trans-unit.source: Minidrivers go by a variety of names, including miniport and miniclass.
trans-unit.target: Minidrivers go by a variety of names, including miniport and miniclass.

trans-unit.source: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:
trans-unit.target: Next, determine which of the following cases describes your driver model recommendation and follow the steps:

trans-unit.source: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.
trans-unit.target: Case 1: The documentation for your technology recommends UMDF.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Visual C++ | Windows Driver | WDF**.

trans-unit.source: In the middle pane, select **User Mode Driver (UMDF)**.
trans-unit.target: In the middle pane, select **User Mode Driver (UMDF)**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439659).
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Writing a UMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439659).

trans-unit.source: **Note** When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: **Note** When you create a new UMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
trans-unit.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most UMDF drivers.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the interfaces that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the interfaces that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.
trans-unit.target: Case 2: The documentation for your technology recommends KMDF.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **WDF**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **WDF**.

trans-unit.source: In the middle pane, select **Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)**.
trans-unit.target: In the middle pane, select **Kernel Mode Driver (KMDF)**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Writing a KMDF Driver Based on a Template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).

trans-unit.source: **Note** When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.
trans-unit.target: **Note** When you create a new KMDF driver, you must select a driver name that has 32 characters or less.

trans-unit.source: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.
trans-unit.target: This length limit is defined in wdfglobals.h.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by most KMDF drivers.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the methods that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the methods that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a minidriver model.
trans-unit.target: Case 3: The documentation for your technology describes a minidriver model.

trans-unit.source: If your device technology has a miniport, miniclass, or some other kind of minidriver model, check to see if Visual Studio has a specific template for the model.
trans-unit.target: If your device technology has a miniport, miniclass, or some other kind of minidriver model, check to see if Visual Studio has a specific template for the model.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver**.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, locate and select **Templates | Visual C++ | Windows Driver**.

trans-unit.source: Browse the list of installed templates to find a template for the type of minidriver you need to write.
trans-unit.target: Browse the list of installed templates to find a template for the type of minidriver you need to write.

trans-unit.source: If there is no template for your type of minidriver under **Windows Driver**, click **Online** and browse the templates that are available online.
trans-unit.target: If there is no template for your type of minidriver under **Windows Driver**, click **Online** and browse the templates that are available online.

trans-unit.source: If you find a template for your type of minidriver, select the template, fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: If you find a template for your type of minidriver, select the template, fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your minidriver.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a driver project that implements the general code required by your minidriver.

trans-unit.source: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.
trans-unit.target: Now you can supply the code that is specific to your device.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: If your device technology has a minidriver model, and you are not able to find a specific template for your type of minidriver, the Windows Driver Model (WDM) template is most likely going to be your starting point.
trans-unit.target: If your device technology has a minidriver model, and you are not able to find a specific template for your type of minidriver, the Windows Driver Model (WDM) template is most likely going to be your starting point.

trans-unit.source: Refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance.
trans-unit.target: Refer to your technology-specific documentation for guidance.

trans-unit.source: In rare cases, you can use KMDF to write a minidriver, but usually the starting point is WDM.
trans-unit.target: In rare cases, you can use KMDF to write a minidriver, but usually the starting point is WDM.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, choose **New | Project**.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select **WDM.**
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in the New Project dialog box, under **Windows Driver**, select **WDM.**

trans-unit.source: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the **Name** and **Location** boxes, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have an empty WDM driver project.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose **Add | New Item**.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver project, and choose **Add | New Item**.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, select **C++ File (.cpp)**, enter a name for your file, and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, select **C++ File (.cpp)**, enter a name for your file, and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: **Note** If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the **.c** extension.
trans-unit.target: **Note** If you want to create a .c file instead of a .cpp file, enter a name that has the **.c** extension.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the documentation for your technology to learn about the functions that you need to implement.

trans-unit.source: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.
trans-unit.target: As you implement and organize your functions, you might decide to add additional .cpp or .c files.
